title: [Datasets] Ideas for improving the dataset classes

labels.name: type: technical debt
labels.description: Indicates that technical debt needs to be solved

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
Some ideas for improvements:
- we iterate x times when parsing from datasets. It should be much more effective to do the parsing in only one iteration.
- columns used for parsing also trigger a "Following columns are not supported by the ... model and are ignored" warning, which is a bit confusing. Avoid this message for columns used for the parsing.
- When skipping rows from a dataset that has no tokens, the warning message should include the original row of the dataset.

title: [TextClassificationRecord] Copy inputs values to text?

labels.name: status: question
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request needs more information

body:
When making a query for `TextClassificationRecord`s, the `text` field contains all the values of the `inputs` dictionary.
Shall we follow the same logic in the client?

Now we have this:
```python
rec = rb.TextClassificationRecord(inputs={"text": "mock"})
rec.text == "mock"

rec = rb.TextClassificationRecord(inputs={"not_text": "mock"})
rec.text is None

rec = rb.TextClassificationRecord(inputs={"text": "mock", "second_text": "mock2})
rec.text is None
```
cc @dvsrepo @frascuchon

title: ci: include es 8.0 in build process
body:
This PR includes required changes to make rubrix compatible with the new elasticsearch 8.x version.

The main changes are:

- Use `id` field as default sort key, instead of the `_id` field, which is disabled as default for this es version
- Avoid to define nested fields in mappings. This configuration was deprecated in previos versions and is not allowed in last version. This changes affect to `metadata.*` fields and how the text searches can be used over them. String metadata fields are defined as keywords, and extends the 2 subfields `text` and `exact` for textual queries. You should use them in query string as follows:
```
metadata.my_field.text:total effort
# or
metadata.my_field.exact:Total Effor~
```

title: Docker-compose and Elasticsearch disk space

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

milestone.title: v0.17.0
milestone.description:
Next Rubrix release milestone

# Features

* Copy input text action #1616

body:
Hi, just started evaluating this project today and hit some issues.

When running Rubrix via docker-compose ( https://rubrix.readthedocs.io/en/stable/getting_started/advanced_setup_guides.html#launching-the-web-app-via-docker-compose ) which is usually used for a quick evaluation.
the docker-compose file only defines memory settings for Elasticsearch.

Problem is, Elasticsearch is by default pretty conservative about free disk space. By default it will refuse to write anything if there's less than 5% disk space or so (don't remember the exact number).

What's worse, the Rubrix client library only reports the following:

```
rubrix.client.sdk.commons.errors.GenericApiError: Rubrix server returned an error with http status: 500
Error details: [{'code': 'opensearchpy.exceptions.TransportError', 'params': {}}]
```

but when checking the server logs you see the full error:

```
opensearchpy.exceptions.TransportError: TransportError(429, 'cluster_block_exception', 'index [.rubrix.datasets-v0] blocked by: [TOO_MANY_REQUESTS/12/disk usage exceeded flood-stage watermark, index has read-only-allow-delete block];')
```

So:
1. The client library should show the *full* error message
2. The docker compose file should raise the default Elasticsearch thresholds for disk space

source venv/bin/activate
pip install .[server]

title: Add a FAQ section

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
All these past months we've been receiving highly recurrent questions. 

I think is important to provide a FAQ section.  I would vote for adding this to the README so it's easier to maintain and extend quickly with new questions and answers.

I have started drafting this. I'd propose we start drafting this here and then do a PR with a first version:

## What is Rubrix?
Rubrix is an open-source MLOps tool for building and managing training data for Natural Language Processing. 

## What can I use Rubrix for?
Rubrix is useful if you want to:

- create a training set for training a model.
- evaluate and improve an existing model.
- monitor an existing model in order to improve it over time and gather more training data.

## What do I need to start using Rubrix?
You need to have a running instance of Elasticsearch and install Rubrix Python library. 

The Python library is used to read and write data into Rubrix. To get started we highly recommend to use Jupyter Notebooks so you might want to install Jupyter Lab, or use jupyter support for VS Code for example.

## How can I "upload" data into Rubrix?
Currently, the only way to upload data into Rubrix is by using the Python library. This is based on the assumption that there's rarely a perfectly prepared dataset in the format expected by the data annotation tool. 

Rubrix is designed to enable fast iteration for users that are closer to data and models, namely data scientists and NLP/ML/Data engineers. If you are familiar with libraries like Weights & Biases or MLFlow, you'll find Rubrix `log` and `load` methods intuitive. That said, Rubrix gives you different shortcuts and utils to make loading data into Rubrix a breed, such as for example the ability to read datasets directly from the Hugging Face Hub.

In summary, the recommend process for uploading data into Rubrix would be following: 

(1) Install Rubrix Python library, 

(2) Open a Jupyter Notebook, 

(3) Make sure you have a Rubrix server instance up and running, 

(4) Read your source dataset using Pandas, Hugging Face datasets, or any other library, 

(5) Do any data preparation, pre-processing, or pre-annotation with a pretrained model, and 

(6) Transform your dataset rows/records into Rubrix records and log them into a Rubrix dataset using `rb.log`. If your dataset is already loaded as a Hugging Face dataset, checks the `read_datasets` method to make this process even simpler.

## Can I use my own Elasticsearch Instance/cluster?
Yes, you can use your own Elasticsearch installation. You only need to perform some configuration, check the Advanced installation guide in the [docs](https://docs.rubrix.ml/).

## How can I train a model
...

title: [TokenClassificationRecord] Alignment issues when token is a white space

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
**Describe the bug**
Not sure if this is really a bug, but it would be nice to support cases where the tokens are white spaces. We are encountering a lot of these cases in the med7 dataset for the metrics blog post.

**To Reproduce**
```python
from rubrix.server.tasks.token_classification.api.model import CreationTokenClassificationRecord
from spacy import load

nlp = load("en_core_web_sm")
text = "every four (4)  "

record = {
    "text": text,
    "tokens": list(map(str, doc)),  # ['every', 'four', '(', '4', ')', ' ']
    "prediction": {"agent": "mock", "entities": [{"start": 0, "end": 16, "label": "mock"}]},
}

CreationTokenClassificationRecord.parse_obj(record)

# AssertionError: Provided entity span every four (4)   is not aligned with provided tokens.
```


**Expected behavior**
Accept entity

**Screenshots**
If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]:
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]:
 - Rubrix Version [e.g. 0.10.0]:
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. rubrix:v0.10.0]:  

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Use dataclasses for client data models

labels.name: type: technical debt
labels.description: Indicates that technical debt needs to be solved

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
`pydantic` data models fit well for api/sdk modelization, but introduce an design overhead for client. Even more for specific customization on init.

The idea is swap the `pydantic` data model to the native `@dataclasses.dataset` . This simplifies the initialization and allow tackle  custom validations.

title: docs: change readme logo
Mismatch between TokenAttributions model and UI

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body:
**Describe the bug**
The `TokenAttributions` model accepts multiple label-attribution pairs, while the UI can only handle one.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```python
import rubrix as rb

record = rb.TextClassificationRecord(
    inputs="mock",
    prediction=[("POSITIVE", 0.9), ("NEGATIVE", 0.1)],
    explanation={"text": [
        rb.TokenAttributions(
            token="mock", attributions={"POSITIVE": 0.5, "NEGATIVE": -0.5}
        )
    ]},
)
```

**Expected behavior**
Maybe for now the model should only accept one label-attribution pair, or the UI should be able to handle various.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: Ubuntu
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: firefox
 - Rubrix Version [e.g. 0.10.0]: master
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: 7.10.2
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. rubrix:v0.10.0]:

title: [LabelModels] The `LabelModel.predict` should optionally return a numpy array
body:
Right now the `LabelModel.predict` method returns a list of records that include the predictions. This is fine if you want to log these records directly to Rubrix again for inspection, but not so good if you want to continue using the predictions for training.
Example from our tutorial:
```python
label_model = Snorkel(weak_labels)

# get records with the predictions from the label model
records = label_model.predict()

# build a simple dataframe with text and the prediction with the highest score
df_train = pd.DataFrame([
    {"text": record.inputs["text"], "label": weak_labels.label2int[record.prediction[0][0]]}
    for record in records
])

# fit the classifier
classifier.fit(
    X=df_train.text,
    y=df_train.label
)
```
I would like to simplify this to:
```python
label_model = Snorkel(weak_labels)

# get records with the predictions from the label model
records, y = label_model.predict(return_y_array=True)

# fit the classifier
classifier.fit(
    X=records.to_pandas().text,
    y=y
)
```

title: feat: Introduce a 'text' argument for the TextClassificationRecord
body:
This PR introduces a `text` argument for the `TextClassificationRecord` to make the records more consistent with each other. It also helps a lot in cases, where we provide a simple string to the `inputs` argument, and when we load the records from Rubrix again, we always have to extract the `text` key from the inputs dict. In the tutorials we often do this:
```
rb.log(TextClassificationRecord(inputs="string"), "mock")
records_df = rb.load("mock")
records_df["text"] = records_df.inputs.map(lambda x: x["text"])
```
With this PR, the recommended way would be:
```
rb.log(TextClassificationRecord(text="string"), "mock")
records_df = rb.load("mock")
```
For now, we still accept strings in the `inputs` argument, but in the future, this should be deprecated.

To Do:
- [x] add tests
- [x] update documentation/tutorials

title: [Metrics] Change default value for the argument 'mentions' in entity_consistency

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
When dealing with metrics (specifically with **entity_consistency**), the default value of the argument 'mentions' is set to 10. With this default value, sometimes it is not possible to obtain data.

If the default value was higher (i.e. **mentions=20**), I think we could get rid of this problem.

title: [Metrics] Symbols count as UPPER tokens or characters for token/entity capitalness metrics

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
When using the **token capitalness** or the **entity capitalness** metrics for analyzing the capitalness on datasets, annotations, and/or predictions, symbols (*, [, (, )...) are counted as **UPPER** results (in other words, as if they were in uppercases). However, Python does not count symbols as uppercase tokens/characters, but the opposite.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior:**
1. Run some of these metrics (i.e. **from rubrix.metrics.token_classification import token_capitalness**), and the same for **token_frequency**. The most frequent results, which are probably symbols, are counted as uppercase tokens.
2. run "(".isupper( ). The result is **FALSE**.

**Expected behavior**
These tokens and entities should be counted as lowercase ones. 

**Additional context**
This problem has been encountered on med7 models.

title: [Metrics] New line character counted as blank in token frequency metrics

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
When computing the **token frequency** in the metrics and plotting it, the new line chat (\n) counts as a blank space and it also is displayed in that way.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior:**
1. Run **from rubrix.metrics.token_classification import token_frequency**
2. Visualize it with a specific dataset (i.e. **token_frequency(name="med7_trf").visualize()**)
3. Look at the most frequent result.

title: Is text2text supported?

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body: **Describe the bug** Based on [this page](https://rubrix.readthedocs.io/en/stable/getting_started/supported_tasks.html#tasks-on-the-roadmaphttps://rubrix.readthedocs.io/en/stable/getting_started/supported_tasks.html#tasks-on-the-roadmap), I think Text2Text is not yet supported, but based on [this discussion](https://github.com/recognai/rubrix/discussions/174), it seems like it is. I think this should be more clear. **To Reproduce** Documentation bug, no steps beyond visiting the links and reading. **Expected behavior** As a potential user evaluating annotation tools for my team, I expect a clear answer about which tasks are supported, and for unsupported tasks, what the roadmap / timeline looks like. **Screenshots** **Environment (please complete the following information):** N/A **Additional context** Just found out about the project, and am very excited about it, and would like to know if it is currently usable for my team, or something to just keep an eye on.

title: feat(datasets): simplify load flow from hf datasets with no rb format
body:
With this PR you can convert hf datasets to rubrix datasets as follow:

```python

import datasets
amazon_reviews = datasets.load_dataset("amazon_reviews_multi", "es", split="train")
rb_ds = rb.DatasetForTextClassification.from_datasets(
    amazon_reviews, 
    inputs=["review_title","review_body"], 
    annotation="stars"
)
# Here you can just log the dataset
rb.log(rb_ds, name="amazon-reviews")
```
We can define similar approach for `metadata` or `text` for the  other tasks, or `tags` for token classification

@dcfidalgo @dvsrepo any suggestion?


TODO:
- [x] Include tests for text2text
- [x] Fix failing tests once hf bug is fixed:

```python
import datasets
ds = datasets.Dataset.from_dict({ "a": [None, [1,2], None, [3,4]]})
ds.map(lambda x: { "b": "b"}).to_pandas() # None values in a becomes empty lists
```

See this PR https://github.com/huggingface/datasets/issues/3676

title: feat(#981): add majority voter with multi label support
body:
Closes #981 

This PR adds a `MajorityVoter` to our label models and supports a `WeakMultiLabels` object. In the multi-label case, this label model simply sets the probability to 1, if at least one rule voted for the respective label. Otherwise, the probability is zero.

I think a lot of the logic can be shared with the FlyingSquid label model, but I would like to do the refactoring in a separate PR. Also, Ruan is working heavily on this label model, so I would like to wait for his PR to go in. 

You can find the tutorial here: https://rubrix.readthedocs.io/en/feat-majority_vote_model/tutorials/weak-supervision-multi-label.html
I'm not super thrilled about the tutorial, mainly because of the bad results. Either the datasets are really challenging, or I'm simply bad at finding good heuristics. I doubt that a more sophisticated label model will bring much improvement, but we can use those results as a baseline. @dvsrepo feedback would be much appreciated!

title: Dataset snapshots and versioning (DVC, S3, HF ...)

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
As a user (e.g., data/ML engineer) I want to be able to persist a snapshot of my data so that I can have better reproducibility. 
As a user I want to be able to easily read and recover a snapshot.


The simplest case is having a `to_disk()` method which stores all necesary info (including rules, tags, etc.). Other ideas are to leverage hf `Dataset` to delegate this.

Question: how is this related to DVC, Pachyderm and others?

Related: https://www.pachyderm.com/blog/pachyderm-label-studio-versioned-data-labeling/

See also argilla-io/roadmap#10

title: Custom Record UI Templates

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

labels.name: area: ux
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Experience (UX)

labels.name: team: frontend
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the frontend team

body:
As a user I want to:

- Show specific fields in my record card (for example metadata fields that are needed for annotation).
- Show fields in a specific order or with a specific style.
- in summary, control how and what is displayed to annotators during the annotation or review process

The configuration could be provided as a mix of a templating language and high-level vue components.

This configuration should be done at the dataset level, with certain user rights, and both from Python and the UI

title: Active Learning Loops

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
As I user I would like to easily define an active learning loop so I don't have to do a lot of configuration to use active learning.

The starting point would be this tutorial: https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/tutorials/notebooks/training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.html and the question is:

1. Can we generalize this configuration?
2. So that users only need to configure the dataset, model and few other things?

title: User Roles and Permissions
body:
## Description

Define a set of roles for users that can restrict the dataset manipulation. Some examples could be:

- **viewer**: only can explore the records. Explore the dataset in a read-only mode
- **annotator**: a role for annotator users. Can create labeling rules, change record annotations
- **reviewer**: for advanced annotation flows. This role can resolve conflicts in the annotation agreement flow ( MUST BE DEFINED)
- **admin**: can change settings, annotate, delete.

title: Webhooks
body:
As a user I want to have the ability to register webhooks so I can trigger certain actions when specific events happen.

One could have triggers for at least:

1. Workspace events
2. Dataset events

Dataset events would add the most value for automation

title: Apply rules and aggregate weak labels in Python Client for Token Classification

labels.name: area: server
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the server

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
As a Python user I want to:

- Read the rules from a Token Classification dataset
- Apply the rules to the dataset (i.e., generating a weak label matrix)
- Aggregate/denoise the resulting weak labels

In principle we should follow the same data model that we use for Text Classification and decide if we want to have a external dependency for the Aggregation/denoising model (e.g., skweak)

title: Usage telemetry

labels.name: area: server
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the server

body:
## Description

Record several usage metrics for the python client and API usage.

The registered event must be well defined and documented to users and could be disabled at any moment.


## Tasks

- [ ] Add metrics documentation (how to disable, which metrics will be collected,...)
- [ ] Minimal event to register:  `/api/me`, `/api/datasets/.../bulk` and API errors
- [ ] Define metrics component (encapsulate communication with segment.io, environment settings,...)
- [ ] Configure the segment.io sources and destinations

title: Annotation Focus mode

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

labels.name: area: ux
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Experience (UX)

labels.name: team: frontend
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the frontend team

body:
## Description

Creating a new UI mode that helps with annotation sessions. 

This mode must be included for all defined tasks and should keep the user interaction as simple as possible and hard oriented to annotation.

### From issue #1851 
**Describe the bug**
With more than 10 labels the button hot-links stop.

**To Reproduce**
Go to token / text-classification and assign >10 label options.

**Expected behavior**
I would expect them to continue on function keys or initial qwerty keys.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25269220/196913426-5c46cf7a-8472-4454-b6f4-b51310d9dc71.png)
